title: Total Products Delivered
problem_statement:
Question: Total Products Delivered

A company manufactures different types of software products. They deliver their products to their N clients. Whenever the company fulfills the complete order of a client, the order ID generated is the sum of the number of products delivered for every committed product type. The head of the sales team wants to find the client-specific data for the total number of products of any type delivered to each client.

Write an algorithm for the head of the sales team to calculate the total number of products of any type delivered to the respective clients.

Input Format

  • The first line of the input consists of an integer numOfClients, representing the number of clients N.
  • The second line consists of N space-separated integers orderID0, orderID1, ..., orderIDN-1, representing the order IDs of the orders delivered to the clients.

Output Format

Print N space-separated integers representing the total products delivered to each client.

Constraints

  • 1 ≤ numOfClients ≤ 106
  • 0 ≤ orderID[i] ≤ 109

Example

Input:
5
1 2 3 4 5
Output:
1 2 3 4 5

Each client receives their respective order ID as the total product delivery amount.

Question: Number of Weeks for Projects

An employee in a company has begun working on N projects (numbered 0 to N-1). Each week, an employee can work on a single module of one of the projects. The modules that are chosen on any two successive weeks should come from different projects. A project can have at most Ci modules. The modules of the projects are such that a module is completed in a week.

Write an algorithm to find the number of weeks during which the employee can work on projects following the above-mentioned rules.

Input Format

  • The first line of the input consists of an integer num, representing the number of projects N.
  • The next line consists of N space-separated integers projC0, projC1, ..., projCN-1, representing the number of modules of the projects.

Output Format

Print an integer representing the maximum number of weeks the employee can work on projects.

Constraints

  • 1 ≤ num ≤ 106
  • 1 ≤ projC[i] ≤ 106

Example

Input:
3
3 2 2
Output:
6

The employee can alternate between projects to complete the maximum number of weeks while ensuring no two successive weeks are on the same project.
